11.59.text:
I want to talk today about something
that is very important to me,

18.01.text: My research is related to climate change.

20.82.text: I've served as a chief scientist at NASA,

23.74.text:
I'm the director of a large
environmental research organization,

28.54.text:
and in that capacity, I tend to talk
to people of all sorts about climate.

32.99.text:
What I'm going to talk
to you about today is climate,

36.24.text:
but more generally speaking,
communicating controversial topics.

40.54.text: And I've talked about climate matters

42.64.text:
to the general public,
to fellow scientists, to legislators,

47.20.text:
to the members of the White House, in both
the Bush and the Obama administration;

51.70.text:
you can imagine those conversations
were probably quite different.

56.54.text:
And I'm going to talk to you
about some of the things I've learned,

60.44.text:
the things I carry forward
in those conversations

63.36.text:
that I hope you'll carry forward
in yours as well.

70.34.text:
Sometimes this reminds me
of my experiences in Washington D.C.,

73.75.text:
but I'll let you to interpret that
however you want.

82.14.text:
words, attitude,
and your clarity of purpose,

85.96.text: and I'll get to each of those in a minute.

87.97.text: But I want to start with a clipping

90.68.text:
from the Washington Post
at the end of last year

96.50.text:
When it was having problems
and overcoming those problems,

99.92.text:
this article came out
in the Washington Post.

103.21.text:
800,000 visits a day, 50,000 people
at one time being able to apply,

108.38.text:
but I want to call your attention to this:
"Democrats optimistic, GOP skeptical."

114.61.text: The same data interpreted very differently

118.67.text:
depending on who's doing
the interpretation.

121.75.text:
What this means, what this
says to me in many cases:

124.96.text:
"It is often less about the data
than the narrative."

130.04.text:
We all have our perceptions
of the world, how it works,

134.96.text:
and we look at the data
through those perceptions,

140.20.text: This is a fundamental thing to understand

142.37.text:
as you communicate
with friends, colleagues, others

145.72.text:
about controversial topics
such as climate change.

152.38.text:
Words set the tone, words convey
your opinion of something,

156.07.text:
they put the audience, the person
you're speaking to in a certain posture

160.90.text:
to receive your message
or to resist your message.

164.00.text: I'm going to give you just a few examples.

168.29.text:
A tax on the wealth
you leave behind after you die,

171.30.text: that is one way of describing it.

173.14.text:
Others choose to describe this
as the death tax,

176.24.text:
the final kick in the pants
by the U.S. government

178.76.text: as you head to your grave.

185.05.text:
To some this is the right to not have
to retreat when you feel threatened

189.72.text:
and actually fight back with deadly force,
even if you could retreat.

194.75.text: To others, this is a license to kill.

197.62.text:
Why not retreat when you can?
Why stay and kill someone?

203.25.text:
The same situations,
but cast very, very differently.

206.84.text: Here are just a few other examples:

208.97.text:
job-killing taxes versus
revenue for national needs;

219.81.text:
Different ways of describing
the same phenomena,

223.84.text:
but the words say something
about how you feel,

226.72.text:
and depending on which of these words
you use when you talk to someone,

230.14.text:
you'll elicit a certain kind of posture,
a certain kind of response.

239.91.text:
Would you want to build
a sandcastle with this kid?

248.88.text:
People, much more than what you say,
remember how you make them feel.

255.05.text:
This is what your attitude does,
it sets the mood of a conversation.

258.97.text:
It will either put people
in a resistive posture,

261.74.text:
if you're forth-coming, if you're strong,
you're coming at them with both barrels,

266.33.text: or, perhaps, a more receptive posture,

268.48.text:
if you're a little more open,
if you're a little more receiving.

273.42.text: The third is purpose, clarity of purpose.

276.28.text:
You need to be clear on your goals.
What is the purpose of your conversation?

281.25.text:
To some people it's just about convincing,
it's just about winning.

286.74.text:
my interest is not so much
about getting a certain outcome,

291.76.text:
my interest is getting them to think
differently than, perhaps, they have.

297.24.text:
And getting myself to think
differently than, perhaps, I have.

301.58.text:
It's a two-way--, it's engagement,
it's not talking at someone,

305.17.text:
it's engaging someone, to move people,
to move the conversation forward.

309.67.text:
So my sort of rules
of engagement, I have four.

313.05.text: The first is understand the context.

315.81.text:
I like to say your adversaries are not
as dumb as you want them to be.

321.96.text: How many times have we all done it:

324.01.text:
"Oh, it's just so stupid!
Why are you so stupid?

327.26.text:
If you could just see things
the way I see them.

329.87.text:
If you knew what I knew,
you'd see things my way."

333.88.text:
People feel the way they feel
because of the values.

337.46.text: It's usually not just that they're dumb,

339.95.text:
it's just that they view things
differently than you do.

343.35.text:
Once you do that, you can frame
your ideas in ways that resonate,

347.46.text:
in ways that connect with people,
meet them where they are.

351.64.text: Don't tell people what to think.

354.13.text:
Understand that beliefs
are rooted in values,

358.21.text:
so when you tell people what to think,
you're directly challenging their values.

364.50.text:
- if you take one thing away
from this talk, please, let it be this -

368.40.text:
don't expect your values
to change other people's beliefs.

373.45.text:
If you're going into a conversation
thinking that because I value this,

378.14.text:
I can convince this person
of the same thing I think,

381.49.text:
you're not going to have
a constructive conversation.

384.96.text:
So understand the context,
frame ideas in ways that resonate,

389.03.text: don't tell people what to think,

391.00.text:
and don't expect your values
to change other people's beliefs.

397.08.text: When I put this into practice,

398.91.text:
when I have a conversation
with a person about climate change,

402.56.text: to get at that, I like to do two things.

405.88.text:
The first is I like to speak in simple,
logical, intuitive statements.

410.51.text:
So I'll use something that we can
both agree on as a starting point.

414.96.text: In the area of climate change, it's this:

417.84.text:
"If we put heat-trapping gas
into the atmosphere, it will trap heat."

422.99.text:
You don't have to be a genius
to understand this statement.

426.86.text:
Most people, you know,
I can get that far in the conversation.

431.02.text:
I'm not thinking about the outcomes,
let's start at the beginning.

434.71.text:
You can argue about how much heat
and what's too much, what's not,

440.10.text:
but what's too much,
what is tolerable.

443.56.text:
But the basic principle:
heat-trapping gas will trap heat.

448.22.text:
The other is we all share
some common core principles.

451.79.text:
We all want to be safe.
We all value freedom.

455.62.text: We all want opportunities to prosper.

459.56.text:
whether I'm talking
to a Republican congressman,

462.56.text:
a Democratic congressman,
Tea Party, independent, whatever.

467.54.text: Those are things we all value.

469.55.text:
Some of us are willing to give up
more of one to gain another,

474.70.text:
but when we start in that place,
we can have a meaningful conversation,

479.19.text: no matter how far apart we may seem to be.

483.30.text:
This is a graph of the Dow Jones
Industrial for the last 110 years,

487.98.text:
the stock market,
the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

493.81.text:
It may not have much on its face to do
with climate in the way you look at it,

499.40.text: If you look at his curve,

500.85.text:
- it's on a logarithmic scale,
so it's a bit compressed -

503.58.text:
but if you look at this curve,
you see that it goes up, it goes down;

508.81.text:
it goes up over the long period,
over the full period of the cycle,

512.86.text:
and over the last decade or two,
it has actually leveled off quite a bit.

517.54.text:
If you look at the climate curve,
the temperature curve,

521.90.text:
it goes up, it goes down,
on balance, goes up quite a bit,

526.96.text:
it has leveled off some
over the last decade.

531.32.text:
I use this analogy because, you know,
everybody wants stocks to go up,

535.79.text:
everybody can look
at the graph of the stock

537.86.text: and get a sense of what it's doing.

539.91.text:
When we do this
in the context of temperature,

542.07.text: I'll bring it back to stocks.

543.59.text: You would never look at one stock,

547.01.text:
you'd never look at one short period
of time to understand the trend.

551.67.text:
If you took a five-year snapshot
of anywhere on here,

555.07.text:
you might see rapid raises,
rapid declines,

558.70.text: you'd never say this is what is telling us

560.87.text:
what the markets
are doing in the long term;

562.96.text: no, you'll look at a longer data set.

566.20.text: The same is true with temperature.

568.28.text: Similarly, the leveling off at the top,

571.40.text:
the basic principles
of economics and investment,

574.60.text:
the odds are the market
is going to continue to go up.

577.26.text: You can't look at that leveling and say:

579.17.text:
"The graph has stopped,
the market is coming down,

581.53.text:
it's going to go back
to what it was in 1902."

586.59.text:
The other thing is you'd never look
at one stock or a handful of stocks

593.57.text:
and say: "This is
what the market is doing."

596.20.text: You want an index, a representative index,

598.71.text: you want SND 500, you want 500 stocks,

601.79.text:
you want to collect enough data
to make meaningful contributions.

605.01.text:
Yet, people do this
with temperature all the time.

608.50.text: People will grab a small snapshot.

611.27.text:
This last summer, Tyler, Texas,
and Lubbock, Texas

615.77.text: had a record-low high temperature in July.

620.76.text:
So it was the lowest high temperature
in July, I think it was 77 degrees,

624.67.text: and people took that and said:

626.32.text:
"Wow, it's done! There is
your climate warming, it's done."

629.90.text:
You can't do that. Nor can take
an extremely hot year and say:

636.24.text:
This is what it's going to be like
from here on now."

639.57.text:
You don't pick narrow time frames,
and you don't pick one place.

644.40.text:
There are places on the Earth
that are cooling,

647.21.text: many places on the Earth that are cooling.

649.22.text:
That does not tell us
what the Earth is doing as a whole,

651.90.text: a collection of the data tell us that.

657.02.text:
This is a reconstruction
of temperature histories

659.75.text:
for the last 1,000 years,
the famous Hockey Stick, it's called.

665.59.text:
- these are different reconstructions,
this is what different people find -

669.74.text:
if these were stocks,
or a stock history of a company,

673.67.text: you'd look at about 1850, 1900 and say:

676.28.text:
"Wow, something happened there.
What did they do?

679.77.text:
Did they change the management?
Did they introduce a new product?

685.62.text:
You'd want to know, you'd dig into it,
but you'd say there was a change there.

689.72.text:
If this were money, you would say
there was a change there,

692.87.text: or [if this were] value of a stock.

695.85.text: The same is true with temperature.

699.02.text:
something happened in the period
of the Industrial Revolution.

704.18.text: By drawing the analogy to the stock,

706.28.text:
I'm sort of taking it out
of the controversial realm

708.85.text:
and saying: "Let's just look at data,
forget our ideologies.

713.80.text:
When looking at it in that context,
you look at it differently.

716.80.text:
You look at it and ask
different kinds of questions.

722.20.text:
So these are climate model
predictions for the future.

726.22.text:
What you see in gray is the past,
what our models say happened before,

730.52.text:
so you get a sense of how good
or bad they are by the uncertainty,

734.22.text: the width of that gray band.

738.47.text: In the future, we see different scenarios.

740.86.text: One, a leveling off of temperature,

742.74.text:
that is if we drastically reduce
greenhouse gas emissions;

746.04.text:
the other, the red at the top,
is 'business as usual' as we call it,

749.86.text: if we don't make any changes

751.21.text:
and just continue
with our activities unabated.

755.30.text: There is a range of futures out there.

758.28.text: This is what the basic physics tell us.

761.14.text: Now, we can have a conversation

762.82.text:
about our differing values
and how we should address this,

765.84.text:
but the basic physics,
the basic principles tell us this.

769.94.text: So I come back to the Earth.

771.70.text: I was a chief scientist at NASA,

773.42.text:
I spent a lot of time looking
at the Earth this way.

775.96.text:
A lot of you look at it up close
and personally, that is great too,

779.12.text: but I come back to the Earth.

781.15.text: I'm not going to sit here and say:

783.15.text:
"You will experience drought.
You will experience flooding.

786.38.text:
Where you live is going
to go up 2 degrees,

789.32.text:
where you live is going
to go up 4 degrees."

791.62.text:
I can't really say that, and I don't think
that's the right conversation to have.

795.51.text:
I think the right conversation to have
is we are stressing the planet,

800.87.text:
we are putting heat-trapping gas
into the atmosphere.

803.96.text:
it is trapping heat,
that causes temperatures to rise,

808.58.text:
and that puts us in a different kind
of risk posture for the future,

817.20.text:
Is the cost of not doing anything
greater than the cost of doing things?

822.62.text:
That is the kind of conversation
you got to have,

825.05.text: and if I come at you with:

826.62.text:
"The world is getting warmer,
it's going to be anarchy,"

831.21.text:
The people that won't,
are those that already believe it,

834.02.text:
and I don't need to have
that conversation.

840.39.text:
And that puts our future
in a very uncertain state.

847.48.text:
This doesn't have to be
a story though about bad news,

855.27.text:
If we look at the challenge
of climate change,

857.56.text:
I think it can actually be
a different kind of story.

861.43.text:
A story about national security,
a story about energy independence,

865.38.text:
a story about prosperity, a story
about giving to our future generations.

870.80.text:
And when cast in that context, sure,
these challenges are current structures,

875.77.text:
but these are the kinds of things
that people value,

878.85.text:
these are the kinds of topics
we can have conversations around.

883.40.text:
And I encourage you, as you talk
about anything controversial,

887.08.text:
think of your narrative,
think of the other person's narrative,

890.09.text:
think about how you can
frame the discussion

893.08.text:
in ways that resonate with people,
in ways that connect with people.

897.15.text:
Finally, I want to leave you
with this last thought.

902.94.text:
One person's sunset
is another person's sunrise.

909.18.text: It's really a matter of your perspective,

911.45.text:
how you view things, where you sit
when you look at the phenomena.

915.68.text: So, as you go out and as you communicate,

918.05.text:
I encourage you all avoid
the sunset and seek the sunrise.
